question: [File: aptos-core/aptos-move/block-executor/src/txn_commit_hook.rs] [Method: on_execution_aborted] [Abort logging] Are aborted transaction events properly logged when on_execution_aborted() is called, or can validators silently drop failed transactions without record? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/block-executor/src/txn_commit_hook.rs] [Method: on_transaction_committed] [Lock ordering] Can hook implementations acquire locks in an order that conflicts with the block executor's locking strategy, causing deadlocks during parallel execution? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/block-executor/src/txn_commit_hook.rs] [Method: on_transaction_committed] [Concurrent modification] If hooks access shared state, can concurrent invocations from parallel execution cause data races not prevented by the Send + Sync bounds? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/block-executor/src/txn_commit_hook.rs] [Method: on_transaction_committed] [Synchronization overhead] Can hooks that perform synchronous operations (like I/O or network calls) block executor threads and degrade throughput during high transaction volume? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/block-executor/src/txn_commit_hook.rs] [Method: on_transaction_committed] [Consensus violation] Can non-deterministic hook implementations cause different validators to diverge in their execution flow, breaking BFT consensus invariants? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/block-executor/src/txn_commit_hook.rs] [Method: on_transaction_committed] [Finality bypass] Can hooks be used to expose uncommitted transaction data to external systems before finality, allowing front-running or MEV attacks? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/block-executor/src/txn_commit_hook.rs] [Method: on_execution_aborted] [Double-execution] If on_execution_aborted() fails to properly mark transactions as aborted, can the same transaction be re-executed, potentially causing double-spending? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/block-executor/src/txn_commit_hook.rs] [Method: on_transaction_committed] [Empty block] Are hooks properly handled for empty blocks with no transactions, or can this edge case cause unexpected behavior like null pointer dereferences? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/block-executor/src/txn_commit_hook.rs] [Method: on_transaction_committed] [Genesis block] During genesis block execution, are hooks properly initialized and called, or can missing initialization cause crashes during network bootstrap? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/block-executor/src/txn_commit_hook.rs] [Method: on_transaction_committed] [Max transactions] At the maximum transaction count per block, can hook invocations cause integer overflow in transaction indices or array indexing? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/block-executor/src/txn_commit_hook.rs] [Method: on_execution_aborted] [Partial block] If block execution is interrupted mid-way, can partially invoked hooks leave the system in an inconsistent state requiring manual recovery? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/block-executor/src/txn_commit_hook.rs] [Trait: TransactionCommitHook] [Version compatibility] Can changes to the TransactionCommitHook interface break compatibility with existing implementations during protocol upgrades, causing validator crashes? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/block-executor/src/txn_commit_hook.rs] [Method: on_transaction_committed] [State migration] During state migration or upgrades, can hooks be called with legacy TransactionOutput formats that cause parsing errors or undefined behavior? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/block-executor/src/txn_commit_hook.rs] [NoOpTransactionCommitHook] [Test coverage] Does using NoOpTransactionCommitHook in tests hide bugs in real hook implementations that only surface in production? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/block-executor/src/txn_commit_hook.rs] [Method: on_transaction_committed] [Fuzz testing] Can fuzzed TransactionOutput values cause hooks to panic or enter infinite loops, indicating insufficient input validation? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/block-executor/src/txn_commit_hook.rs] [Method: on_transaction_committed] [Privacy leak] Can hook implementations leak private transaction information (amounts, recipients) to external systems before transactions are publicly visible on-chain? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/block-executor/src/txn_commit_hook.rs] [Method: on_transaction_committed] [Timing attack] Can the timing of hook invocations leak information about transaction execution paths, enabling timing-based attacks to extract sensitive data? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/block-executor/src/txn_commit_hook.rs] [Method: on_transaction_committed] [VM interaction] Can hooks be called during Move VM execution in a way that violates VM invariants, such as modifying VM state during bytecode execution? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/block-executor/src/txn_commit_hook.rs] [Method: on_transaction_committed] [Storage consistency] If hooks interact with AptosDB directly, can concurrent hook invocations cause storage corruption or inconsistent Merkle tree states? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/block-executor/src/txn_commit_hook.rs] [Method: on_execution_aborted] [Mempool interaction] Can on_execution_aborted() hooks incorrectly signal the mempool to retry aborted transactions, causing infinite retry loops? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/block-executor/src/txn_commit_hook.rs] [Method: on_transaction_committed] [Byzantine hook] Can a Byzantine validator use a malicious hook implementation to silently drop transaction commit notifications for specific addresses, enabling selective censorship? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/block-executor/src/txn_commit_hook.rs] [Method: on_execution_aborted] [Abort manipulation] Can Byzantine validators use hooks to incorrectly report transaction aborts, causing honest validators to diverge in their view of committed transactions? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/block-executor/src/txn_commit_hook.rs] [Method: on_transaction_committed] [Equivocation] Can hooks be used by Byzantine validators to send different cross-shard messages to different shards, enabling equivocation attacks? (Critical)
